items.content_html:
This PR prepares the MathML docs (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/MathML) for Markdowning.

After this PR the only unconverted element is the table in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/MathML/Attribute which should stay in HTML because it will be too wide in GFM.

Technically I ought to convert all the examples, like this one:

content/files/en-us/web/mathml/element/mfrac/index.html

Line 50 in ca43b81

<p>Your browser rendering: <math> <mfrac bevelled="true"> <mfrac> <mi> a </mi> <mi> b </mi> </mfrac> <mfrac> <mi> c </mi> <mi> d </mi> </mfrac> </mfrac> </math></p>

...to be live samples, but it doesn't really seem worth it.
items.title: [Markdown][MathML] Prepare MathML for Markdowning

items.content_html:
This PR prepares the WebDriver docs (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/WebDriver) for Markdowning.

After this PR the only unconverted element is the table in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/WebDriver/Capabilities/firefoxOptions, which will stay in HTML because it has cells containing block elements.
items.title: [Markdown][Webdriver] Prepare WebDriver for Markdowning

Currently the example found in the MutationObserver article (https://codepen.io/webgeeker/full/YjrZgg/) doesn't work; instead of resizing, it maintains the same size and will show a scroll bar when the size of the contenteditable list exceeds the initial size.

items.content_html:
This updates the perspective property and perspective() function to
reflect some existing errors (regarding negative values) and some new
CSS working group resolutions that have at this point all shipped in at
least one of Firefox or Chrome (and which I think are all likely to ship
in the other soon, and hopefully in Safari as well):

  • w3c/csswg-drafts#413 resolved that 0 is
    allowed in both the property and the function, but values of both that
    are less than 1px are clamped to 1px.

  • w3c/csswg-drafts#6488 added the none value
    to the perspective() function; it was already a value of the
    perspective property.

It also adds some clarification about what large/small/none values mean.

Supporting details

  • implementing perspective(none): Mozilla bug 1725207, Chromium bug 1253596, WebKit bug 231361
  • clamping of perspective less than 1px: Chromium code change, Chromium announcement, Mozilla bug

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Updates to CSS perspective property and perspective() function.

items.content_html: the title was just <wbr>. Pages like td have titles like " <td> the table celll element
items.title: title of a few elements missing context in the title

items.content_html:
A minor change. When the article covers the main tools (that have the screenshots such as Web Console and JavaScript Debugger) I noticed that the description for that tool is after the screenshot. The usability issues with this are:
(1) When a newish user see's the screenshot they won't really know what they are looking at until they look at the text after the screenshot.
(2) It is unclear, at first, if the descriptive text belongs to the screenshot below or after the text.

I just copied and pasted the descriptive text (in the

tag) from the bottom of the image to the top of the image right under the title. You should find that more users will understand immediately what they are look at when they can read the descriptive text right before starring at the image. If anything the descriptive text can remind some users what the panel is for so they remember what they are looking at.

Summary

Motivation

Supporting details

Related issues

  • omittied the aria/Roles as that is in a different PR
  • ommitted a few files that I will be deleting; so no need to create a md file for them. (deleting files will be a different PR)

❓ Why?
Because. That's why!
And, because it's what we do.

items.content_html:
Summary

Fix the note in the Meaning column for character ^ which says:

This character has a different meaning when it appears at the start of a group.

to say

This character has a different meaning when it appears at the start of a range.

Motivation

I am unable to find any difference in meaning when ^ is used in a group,
at the start or otherwise. It does differ when used in a range.

Supporting details

I am unable to find anything in ECMA 262 22.2 RegExp (Regular Expression) Objects (particularly 22.2.2.6 Assertion) which indicates that the behavior of ^ differs inside and outside a group.

console.assert(/^H/.test('Hi') === /(^H)/.test('Hi'));
console.assert(/^H/.test('hi') === /(^H)/.test('hi'));

I suspect this note is referring to the different behavior when used in a
CharacterClass, referred to as a range elsewhere in the docs, where it denotes inverting the class/range. This is also discussed in the "Different meaning of '?!' combination usage in Assertions and Ranges" section of the same file.

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error

Thanks for considering,
Kevin
items.title: RegExp Assertions: fix note about ^ in group

items.content_html:
This is part of update for FF94 in #9366

The API has the following changes w.r.t. current docs (by inspection and testing)

  • Sanitizer.getConfiguration()
  • Sanitizer.sanitizeToString() method removed.
  • Element.setHTML() method added.
  • Some new configuration options, but these are still not actually supported anywhere.

There is still a fair bit to do so putting in draft for now.
spec is key resource, as is github repo and setHTML pr
items.title: FF94 : Updates to sanitizer API

items.content_html:
Fixes #9170

Code inspection shows that AV1 is only disabled on a small subset OS/hardware. This clarifies and links to bug for remaining part. Many thanks to @jwatt
items.title: FF supports AV1 but not on android and windows on ARM

This is the result of running:

npx prettier --write ./files/en-us/web/javascript

...which has the effect of prettifying the JS code blocks in the JS documentation.

Just an experiment to see if we might want to do this.
items.title: Prettify code blocks in JavaScript docs
